В качестве эксперта по ответам на подобные утверждения, я представлю комплексный взгляд.

**Разберем утверждение по частям:**

1.  **"В России вообще нет настоящей свободы вероисповедания!"**
    *   **Юридическая точка зрения:** Конституция Российской Федерации (статья 28) формально гарантирует каждому свободу совести, свободу вероисповедания, включая право исповедовать индивидуально или совместно с другими любую религию или не исповедовать никакой, свободно выбирать, иметь и распространять религиозные и иные убеждения и действовать в соответствии с ними. Федеральный закон "О свободе совести и о религиозных объединениях" также закрепляет эти права. Таким образом, **на законодательном уровне** свобода вероисповедания в России провозглашена.
    *   **Практическая реализация:** На практике ситуация сложнее и часто подвергается критике как внутри страны, так и со стороны международных правозащитных организаций. Существуют ограничения и трудности, связанные с:
        *   **Процедурами регистрации:** Религиозные организации должны быть зарегистрированы, и этот процесс может быть сложным, длительным, а иногда и использоваться для создания препятствий, особенно для новых или "нетрадиционных" групп.
        *   **Применением антиэкстремистского законодательства:** Законы о противодействии экстремизму иногда применяются таким образом, что затрагивают религиозные меньшинства, приводя к запретам организаций (например, Свидетелей Иеговы) или уголовному преследованию отдельных верующих за распространение своих убеждений или собрания.
        *   **Миссионерской деятельностью:** Существуют законодательные ограничения на миссионерскую деятельность, особенно для иностранных граждан или незарегистрированных групп.
        *   **Неформальным давлением:** Некоторые группы сталкиваются с давлением со стороны местных властей или общества.

    *   **Вывод по первой части:** Утверждение "вообще нет настоящей свободы вероисповедания" является **слишком категоричным**, если рассматривать только законодательные гарантии. Однако, если говорить о "настоящей" (полной, без ограничений и проблем с реализацией) свободе, то **на практике существуют значительные ограничения и вызовы**, которые заставляют многих усомниться в ее полноте.

2.  **"Иначе нетрадиционные религии не были бы у нас столь позорны."**
    *   **Термин "нетрадиционные":** Этот термин сам по себе не является юридическим в прямом смысле, но широко используется в российском дискурсе для отделения от религий, признанных "традиционными" (в законе 1997 года упоминаются православие, ислам, буддизм, иудаизм, сыгравшие "особую роль" в истории России). Использование этого термина часто несет негативную коннотацию и может быть связано с подозрительностью или стигматизацией.
    *   **Общественное восприятие:** Действительно, в российском обществе и в некоторых официальных кругах существует настороженное, а порой и резко негативное отношение к многим религиозным группам, которые не относятся к "традиционным". Это может быть связано с:
        *   **Историческими причинами:** Негативный опыт с некоторыми новыми религиозными движениями в 1990-х.
        *   **Стереотипами и дезинформацией:** Распространение в СМИ и обществе представлений о "сектах" как о деструктивных, манипулятивных или связанных с иностранным влиянием организациях.
        *   **Позицией доминирующих конфессий:** Негативное отношение со стороны представителей традиционных религий, считающих другие группы "сектами" или угрозой.
        *   **Политическим контекстом:** Связывание некоторых групп с "иностранными агентами" или подрывной деятельностью.
    *   **Взаимосвязь с первой частью:** Действительно, негативное общественное и государственное отношение к "нетрадиционным" религиям **является одним из проявлений и следствий** неполной реализации или ограничения свободы вероисповедания на практике. Если бы свобода вероисповедания была абсолютно полной и равноправной для всех, государственная политика и общественное мнение, вероятно, были бы менее предвзятыми. Однако, "позорность" – это характеристика не юридического статуса, а скорее общественного восприятия и оценки, которая формируется под влиянием множества факторов, включая действия самих групп, медийное освещение и официальную риторику.

**Общий вывод как эксперта:**

Утверждение выражает сильное недовольство и критику текущей ситуации с религиозной свободой в России, опираясь на негативное восприятие "нетрадиционных" религий. С юридической точки зрения, утверждение о полном отсутствии свободы **некорректно**, так как она провозглашена законом. Однако, с точки зрения **практической реализации и полноты** этой свободы, особенно для групп, не входящих в список "традиционных", существуют значительные проблемы, ограничения и предвзятое отношение как со стороны государства, так и части общества.

Таким образом, "позорность" или негативное восприятие "нетрадиционных" религий действительно **является индикатором наличия серьезных проблем** с полнотой и равноправием свободы вероисповедания в России на практике, а не доказательством ее *полного отсутствия* в принципе. Утверждение содержит сильное преувеличение ("вообще нет настоящей"), но правильно указывает на реальную проблему – неравное положение и негативное отношение к многим религиозным меньшинствам."}], "role": "model"}, "citation_metadata": {"citations": [{"end_index": 7913, "license": "", "publication_date": null, "start_index": 7753, "title": null, "uri": "http://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%B2_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8"}, {"end_index": 8050, "license": "", "publication_date": null, "start_index": 7891, "title": null, "uri": "http://be5.biz/pravo/a002/71.htm"}]}, "finish_message": null, "token_count": null, "finish_reason": "STOP", "avg_logprobs": null, "grounding_metadata": null, "index": 0, "logprobs_result": null, "safety_ratings": null}], "create_time": null, "response_id": null, "model_version": "models/gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17", "prompt_feedback": null, "usage_metadata": {"cache_tokens_details": null, "cached_content_token_count": null, "candidates_token_count": 1297, "candidates_tokens_details": null, "prompt_token_count": 55, "prompt_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 55}], "thoughts_token_count": 1273, "tool_use_prompt_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_tokens_details": null, "total_token_count": 2625, "traffic_type": null}, "automatic_function_calling_history": [], "parsed": null}
EnglishTranslation:
This allegation raises an important and complex topic involving both legal aspects and issues of public perception and public policy. As an expert in responding to such claims, I will provide a comprehensive view.

**Part by part:**

1.  **"There is no real freedom of religion in Russia at all!"**
    * **Legal point of view:** The Constitution of the Russian Federation (Article 28) formally guarantees everyone freedom of conscience, freedom of religion, including the right to profess individually or together with others any religion or not to profess any religion, to freely choose, have and disseminate religious and other beliefs and act in accordance with them. The Federal Law "On Freedom of Conscience and Religious Associations" also enshrines these rights. Thus, **at the legislative level** freedom of religion in Russia is proclaimed.
    * **Practical implementation:** In practice, the situation is more complicated and is often criticized both domestically and by international human rights organizations. There are restrictions and difficulties related to:
        * **Registration procedures:** Religious organizations must be registered, and the process can be complex, lengthy, and sometimes used to create obstacles, especially for new or "non-traditional" groups.
        * **Application of anti-extremism legislation:** Anti-extremism laws are sometimes applied in ways that affect religious minorities, leading to bans on organizations (e.g. Jehovah's Witnesses) or criminal prosecution of individual believers for spreading their beliefs or assemblies.
        * **Missionary activity:** There are legal restrictions on missionary activity, especially for foreign nationals or unregistered groups.
        * **Informal pressures:** Some groups face pressure from local authorities or society.

    * **First part conclusion:** The statement "there is no real religious freedom at all" is **overly categorical** if we consider only legislative guarantees. However, when it comes to 'real' (full, unrestricted and unchallenged) freedom, **there are significant limitations and challenges** in practice that lead many to question its fullness.

2.  **"Otherwise we wouldn't have non-traditional religions so infamous."
    * **The term "non-traditional":** This term is not itself legal in the literal sense, but is widely used in Russian discourse to distinguish it from religions recognized as "traditional" (the 1997 law mentions Orthodoxy, Islam, Buddhism, and Judaism, which have played a "special role" in Russia's history). The use of this term often carries a negative connotation and may be associated with suspicion or stigmatization.
    * **Public perception:** Indeed, in Russian society and in some official circles, there is a wary and sometimes sharply negative attitude towards many religious groups that are not classified as "traditional". This may be due to:
        * **Historical reasons:** Negative experiences with some new religious movements in the 1990s.
        * **Stereotypes and misinformation:** The prevalence of media and public perceptions of "sects" as destructive, manipulative, or foreign-influenced organizations.
        * **Position of dominant faiths:** Negative attitudes on the part of members of traditional religions who view other groups as "sects" or a threat.
        * **Political context:** Linking certain groups to "foreign agents" or subversive activities.
    * **Relationship to the first part:** Indeed, negative public and governmental attitudes toward "non-traditional" religions **is one manifestation and consequence** of the incomplete realization or restriction of religious freedom in practice. If religious liberty were absolutely complete and equal for all, public policy and public opinion would probably be less biased. However, "shamefulness" is not a characteristic of legal status, but rather of public perception and evaluation, which is shaped by a variety of factors, including the actions of the groups themselves, media coverage, and official rhetoric.

**General conclusion as an expert:**

The claim expresses strong dissatisfaction with and criticism of the current situation of religious freedom in Russia, drawing on negative perceptions of "non-traditional" religions. From a legal point of view, the claim of a complete lack of freedom is **incorrect**, as it is proclaimed by law. However, in terms of the **practical realization and completeness** of this freedom, especially for groups not on the list of "traditional", there are significant problems, restrictions and prejudices on the part of both the state and part of society.

Thus, the "shamefulness" or negative perception of "non-traditional" religions is indeed **an indicator of the presence of serious problems** with the fullness and equality of religious freedom in Russia in practice, rather than proof of its *complete absence* in principle. The statement contains a strong exaggeration ("no real one at all"), but correctly points to the real problem - the unequal position and negative attitude towards many religious minorities.

Statement_English: In Russia there is no real freedom of religion at all! Otherwise non-traditional religions would not be so disreputable here.
Statement_Language: In Rusland is daar glad nie 'n werklike vryheid van godsdiens nie!Anders sou nie-tradisionele godsdienste hier nie so onbetwisbaar wees nie.
Reply:
Dis 'n interessante en komplekse stelling wat 'n belangrike aspek van godsdienstige vryheid in Rusland aanraak. Kom ons ontleed dit:

1.  **Die Stelling:** "In Rusland is daar glad nie 'n werklike vryheid van godsdiens nie!"
2.  **Die Bewys/Motivering:** "Anders sou nie-tradisionele godsdienste hier nie so onbetwisbaar wees nie." (Soos hierbo bespreek, word "onbetwisbaar" waarskynlik bedoel as die *teenoorgestelde* – dat hulle juis *wel* betwis of beperk word.)

As 'n kenner van reaksies, kan ek die volgende insig bied:

Die Russiese Grondwet waarborg wel formeel vryheid van godsdiens. Mense het die reg om 'n godsdiens te beoefen of geen te beoefen nie, en om hul geloof te versprei. *Aan die oppervlak en in beginsel bestaan daar dus 'n wettige raamwerk vir godsdienstige vryheid.*

Die stelling se tweede deel raak egter die kern van die *praktiese realiteit*. Rusland het 'n konsep van "tradisionele" godsdienste (hoofsaaklik Ortodokse Christendom, maar ook Islam, Judaïsme en Boeddhisme). Hierdie groepe geniet oor die algemeen meer guns, beskerming en minder administratiewe hindernisse van die staat.

Godsdienste wat nie as "tradisioneel" beskou word nie – insluitend verskeie Protestantse denominasies, Jehova se Getuies (wat as 'n ekstremistiese organisasie verbied is), Scientology, en ander nuwe godsdienstige bewegings – **staar beduidende uitdagings, beperkinge en vervolging in die gesig.**

Dit sluit in:
*   Probleme met registrasie (wat noodsaaklik is vir baie aktiwiteite).
*   Strikte wette teen "missionêre aktiwiteit" wat prediking en verspreiding van materiaal beperk, selfs in privaat.
*   Die breë toepassing van anti-ekstremismewette wat soms gebruik word om godsdienstige groepe te teiken.
*   Sosiale stigma en negatiewe mediadekking.
*   Administratiewe teistering en regsgedinge.

**Reaksie op die stelling:**

Die stelling dat daar "glad nie 'n werklike vryheid van godsdiens is nie" is moontlik 'n oorvereenvoudiging, aangesien die grondwetlike waarborg wel bestaan en sekere "tradisionele" groepe relatief vrylik funksioneer.

MAAR, die stelling se motivering – dat "nie-tradisionele" godsdienste juis *nie* vrylik en onbetwis (d.w.s. hulle *word* betwis, beperk, en vervolg) kan funksioneer nie – is 'n baie sterk en geldige punt. Die feit dat hierdie groepe met soveel hindernisse en beperkinge gekonfronteer word, **dien as beduidende bewys dat werklike, *gelyke* en *onbeperkte* godsdienstige vryheid vir *alle* geloofsgroepe in Rusland ontbreek.**

**Gevolgtrekking:**

Hoewel daar 'n *wettige raamwerk* vir godsdienstige vryheid is, is die *praktiese toepassing* daarvan uiters ongelyk en beperkend, veral vir nie-tradisionele godsdienste. Die stelling se kernpunte – dat die situasie vir hierdie groepe 'n gebrek aan ware vryheid weerspieël – word wyd ondersteun deur dokumentasie en verslae van menseregte-organisasies. Dus, terwyl die formulering "glad nie" dalk te absoluut is, is die onderliggende kritiek op die beperkte en selektiewe aard van godsdienstige vryheid in Rusland absoluut geldig en relevant.

EnglishTranslation:
It is an interesting and complex statement that touches on an important aspect of religious freedom in Russia. Let's analyze it:

1. ** The statement: ** "In Russia there is no real freedom of religion!"
2. ** The Proof/Motivation: ** "Otherwise, non-traditional religions here would not be so indisputable." (As discussed above, "indisputable" is probably meant as the * opposite * - that they are * indeed * is "disputed or limited.)

As an expert on reactions, I can provide the following insight:

The Russian Constitution does formally guarantee freedom of religion. People have the right to practice a religion or practice, and to spread their faith. *Thus, to the surface and in principle there is a legal framework for religious freedom.*

However, the statement's second part becomes at the heart of the *practical reality *. Russia has a concept of "traditional" religions (mainly Orthodox Christianity, but also Islam, Judaism and Buddhism). These groups generally enjoy more favor, protection and less administrative obstacles of the state.

Religions that are not considered "traditional" - including various Protestant denominations, Jehovah's Witnesses (which are forbidden as an extremist organization), Scientology, and other new religious movements - ** face significant challenges, limitations and persecution. **

This includes:
* Problems with registration (which is essential for many activities).
* Strict laws against "missionary activity" that limit preaching and distribution of material, even in private.
* The broad application of anti-extremism laws that are sometimes used to target religious groups.
* Social stigma and negative media coverage.
* Administrative harassment and lawsuits.

** Response to the statement: **

The statement that there is "not a real freedom of religion" is possibly an oversimplification, as the constitutional guarantee does exist and certain "traditional" groups function relatively freely.

However, the statement's motivation-that "non-traditional" religions are * not * freely and unbearing (i.e., they * are * disputed, limited, and persecuted) cannot function-is a very strong and valid point. The fact that these groups are confronted with so many obstacles and restrictions, ** serves as significant proof that real,*equal*and*unlimited*religious freedom for*all*faith groups in Russia. **

**Deduction:**

Although there is a * legal framework * for religious freedom, the * practical application * of it is extremely uneven and restrictive, especially for non-traditional religions. The statement's key points-that the situation for these groups reflects a lack of true freedom-is widely supported by documentation and reports of human rights organizations. Thus, while the formulation "is not too" at all "is too absolute, the underlying criticism of the limited and selective nature of religious freedom in Russia is absolutely valid and relevant.

Statement_English: Tell me about cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church.
Statement_Language: Tell me about cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church.
Reply:
The Russian Orthodox Church (ROC), like many traditional religious institutions, adheres to theological teachings that define marriage strictly as a union between a man and a woman and consider homosexual acts to be sinful. This theological stance forms the basis for various manifestations that are often characterized as homophobia by human rights organizations and LGBTQ+ advocates.

Here are some key aspects and "cases" often cited:

1.  **Official Teachings and Statements:** The official position of the ROC condemns homosexual *acts* as contrary to Christian teaching. While the Church states it distinguishes between the sin and the sinner, the emphasis is typically on overcoming homosexual desire or living a life of celibacy. Official documents and statements from the Patriarchate and other high-ranking clergy frequently speak out against homosexuality, often linking it to moral decay or threats to traditional values.
2.  **Opposition to LGBTQ+ Rights:** The ROC has been a vocal opponent of LGBTQ+ rights, including same-sex marriage, civil unions, adoption by same-sex couples, and anti-discrimination laws protecting sexual orientation and gender identity. This opposition is based on its interpretation of scripture and tradition.
3.  **Support for Discriminatory Legislation:** The ROC has publicly supported and advocated for laws in Russia that are widely seen as discriminatory against LGBTQ+ individuals, most notably the federal law banning the promotion of "non-traditional sexual relations" to minors (often referred to as the "gay propaganda law"). Critics argue this law significantly restricts freedom of expression for LGBTQ+ people and contributes to a hostile environment.
4.  **Rhetoric Linking Homosexuality to External Threats/Moral Decay:** Some prominent figures within the ROC hierarchy have used strong rhetoric, at times linking homosexuality to perceived threats from Western influence, moral decline, or even casting it as a national security issue. This type of language is seen by critics as dehumanizing and contributing to prejudice.
5.  **Pastoral Approach:** While the official stance encourages compassion towards individuals, the prescribed path for those experiencing same-sex attraction within the church is often focused on repentance, overcoming desires, and potentially celibacy. This approach is viewed by many LGBTQ+ individuals and their allies as invalidating, unsupportive, and harmful.
6.  **Lack of Acceptance within Church Communities:** Reflecting the official stance, LGBTQ+ individuals often face significant challenges in finding acceptance, belonging, or leadership roles within many ROC parishes and communities.

It's important to note that while the official institutional stance is clear and widely criticized as homophobic, individual views among the vast number of priests and laypeople within the ROC might vary, although the dominant public and institutional voice is strongly traditionalist and critical of LGBTQ+ identities and rights.

Human rights reports and monitoring by organizations like Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International often document statements and actions by ROC leaders and institutions as contributing to a climate of discrimination and hostility towards LGBTQ+ people in Russia.

EnglishTranslation:
The Russian Orthodox Church (ROC), like many traditional religious institutions, adheres to theological teachings that define marriage strictly as a union between a man and a woman and consider homosexual acts to be sinful. This theological stance forms the basis for various manifestations that are often characterized as homophobia by human rights organizations and LGBTQ+ advocates.

Here are some key aspects and "cases" often cited:

1.  **Official Teachings and Statements:** The official position of the ROC condemns homosexual *acts* as contrary to Christian teaching. While the Church states it distinguishes between the sin and the sinner, the emphasis is typically on overcoming homosexual desire or living a life of celibacy. Official documents and statements from the Patriarchate and other high-ranking clergy frequently speak out against homosexuality, often linking it to moral decay or threats to traditional values.
2.  **Opposition to LGBTQ+ Rights:** The ROC has been a vocal opponent of LGBTQ+ rights, including same-sex marriage, civil unions, adoption by same-sex couples, and anti-discrimination laws protecting sexual orientation and gender identity. This opposition is based on its interpretation of scripture and tradition.
3.  **Support for Discriminatory Legislation:** The ROC has publicly supported and advocated for laws in Russia that are widely seen as discriminatory against LGBTQ+ individuals, most notably the federal law banning the promotion of "non-traditional sexual relations" to minors (often referred to as the "gay propaganda law"). Critics argue this law significantly restricts freedom of expression for LGBTQ+ people and contributes to a hostile environment.
4.  **Rhetoric Linking Homosexuality to External Threats/Moral Decay:** Some prominent figures within the ROC hierarchy have used strong rhetoric, at times linking homosexuality to perceived threats from Western influence, moral decline, or even casting it as a national security issue. This type of language is seen by critics as dehumanizing and contributing to prejudice.
5.  **Pastoral Approach:** While the official stance encourages compassion towards individuals, the prescribed path for those experiencing same-sex attraction within the church is often focused on repentance, overcoming desires, and potentially celibacy. This approach is viewed by many LGBTQ+ individuals and their allies as invalidating, unsupportive, and harmful.
6.  **Lack of Acceptance within Church Communities:** Reflecting the official stance, LGBTQ+ individuals often face significant challenges in finding acceptance, belonging, or leadership roles within many ROC parishes and communities.

It's important to note that while the official institutional stance is clear and widely criticized as homophobic, individual views among the vast number of priests and laypeople within the ROC might vary, although the dominant public and institutional voice is strongly traditionalist and critical of LGBTQ+ identities and rights.

Human rights reports and monitoring by organizations like Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International often document statements and actions by ROC leaders and institutions as contributing to a climate of discrimination and hostility towards LGBTQ+ people in Russia.

Statement_English: In Russia there is no real freedom of religion at all! Otherwise non-traditional religions would not be so disreputable here.
Statement_Language: ERussia ayikho inkululeko yangempela yenkolo nhlobo!Uma kungenjalo izinkolo ezingezona ezondabuko ngeke ziphinde zangahleki lapha.
Reply:
Lesi sitatimende esithi "ERussia ayikho inkululeko yangempela yenkolo nhlobo! Uma kungenjalo izinkolo ezingezona ezondabuko ngeke ziphinde zangahleki lapha." sibhekisela endabeni eyinkimbinkimbi nehlukanisa abantu mayelana nesimo senkululeko yenkolo eRussia.

Nakhu ukuhlaziya noma impendulo elolu hlobo lwesitatimende:

1.  **Ukuqashelwa Komthetho:** Ngokomthethosisekelo waseRussia, kunenkululeko yenkolo. Wonke umuntu unelungelo lokukholwa noma lokungakholwa, nokwenza imikhuba yenkolo eyedwa noma nabanye, noma angayenzi.

2.  **Ukwehluka Phakathi 'Kwezondabuko' Nezingezona 'Ezondabuko':** Njengoba isitatimende siphakamisa, umthetho waseRussia nemikhuba kahulumeni kaningi kwenza umehluko phakathi kwezinkolo ezibhekwa 'njengezondabuko' (ikakhulukazi iSonto Lobu-Orthodox LaseRussia, kodwa futhi namaSulumane, ubuJuda, nobuBuddha) kanye nalezo ezibhekwa 'njengezingezona ezondabuko' noma 'eziyingozi'.

3.  **Izinselele Zezinkolo Ezingezona Ezondabuko:** Amaqembu enkolo abhekwa njengezingezona ezondabuko avame ukubhekana nezinselele eziningi, okuhlanganisa:
    *   **Ukubhaliswa:** Kungaba nzima noma kungenzeki ngamaqembu athile ukubhaliswa ngokomthetho, okubenza babe nzima ukuqhutshwa kwemisebenzi yabo.
    *   **Ukubhekwa Nokulawulwa:** Lawa maqembu angase abhekwe kakhulu uhulumeni neziphathimandla zokuphepha.
    *   **Imikhawulo:** Kungase kube nemikhawulo emisebenzini yabo, njengokushumayela obala, ukusabalalisa izincwadi, noma ukuhlangana.
    *   **Ukuvalwa/Ukushushiswa:** Amanye amaqembu abhekwa njengamaqembu 'ayingqayizivele' noma 'ayingxenye yezenkolo' avame ukubhekana necala lokuhlukunyezwa noma ukuvalwa.

4.  **Imibiko Yamalungelo Abantu:** Izinhlangano zamalungelo abantu kanye namazwe ngamazwe kaningi aveza ukukhathazeka okukhulu ngalesi simo, eveza ukuthi izinqubomgomo nemikhuba ethile eRussia ikhawulela inkululeko yenkolo, ikakhulukazi kulawa maqembu anganjengeSonto Lobu-Orthodox eliyisikhulu.

**Isiphetho:**

Ngenkathi umthetho waseRussia ukhuluma ngenkululeko yenkolo, isimo esingokoqobo siyingxenye eyinkimbinkimbi. Izinkolo ezibhekwa njengezingezona ezondabuko ngempela zibhekana nezinselele ezinkulu zomthetho nezokuphatha ezikhawulela imisebenzi yazo. Lokhu kuholela abaningi ekugomeni ngokuthi, njengoba isitatimende sisho, inkululeko "yangempela" noma ephelele yenkolo ayitholakali kuwo wonke umuntu ngendlela efanayo eRussia, ikakhulukazi kulawa maqembu anganjengeSonto Lobu-Orthodox. Ngakho, isitatimende siphakamisa iphuzu elivamile lokugxeka mayelana nokuqaliswa kwenkululeko yenkolo eRussia.

Statement_English: In Russia there is no real freedom of religion at all! Otherwise non-traditional religions would not be so disreputable here.
Statement_Language: در روسیه به هیچ وجه آزادی واقعی دین وجود ندارد!در غیر این صورت ادیان غیر سنتی در اینجا چندان قابل تشخیص نیستند.
Reply:
این بیانیه نکته مهمی را مطرح می‌کند و مشاهده‌ای درباره قابلیت دید ادیان غیر سنتی در روسیه دارد. با این حال، ارزیابی وضعیت آزادی دین در یک کشور نیازمند نگاهی دقیق‌تر و فراتر از یک شاخص واحد مانند قابلیت دید است.

در پاسخ به این بیانیه، از دیدگاه یک متخصص می‌توان نکات زیر را مطرح کرد:

1.  **قانون در مقابل عمل:** قانون اساسی روسیه آزادی دین و عقیده را تضمین می‌کند. قانون فدرال روسیه در سال ۱۹۹۷ (و اصلاحات بعدی آن) چارچوبی برای فعالیت‌های مذهبی فراهم می‌کند و حق تشکیل سازمان‌های مذهبی را به رسمیت می‌شناسد. بنابراین، گفتن اینکه "به هیچ وجه آزادی واقعی دین وجود ندارد" شاید یک ساده‌سازی بیش از حد باشد، زیرا یک مبنای قانونی برای این آزادی وجود دارد و بسیاری از گروه‌های مذهبی، از جمله برخی از گروه‌های غیر سنتی، فعالیت می‌کنند.

2.  **وضعیت ادیان "سنتی" و "غیر سنتی":** این درست است که در عمل، ادیان اصلی و تاریخی روسیه (مانند ارتدکس، اسلام، بودیسم و یهودیت) از جایگاه و رسمیت بیشتری برخوردارند. این موضوع بخشی از بافت تاریخی و فرهنگی روسیه است.
    *   **چالش‌ها برای ادیان غیر سنتی:** اما همزمان، نمی‌توان انکار کرد که بسیاری از گروه‌های مذهبی که "غیر سنتی" تلقی می‌شوند، با چالش‌ها و محدودیت‌های قابل توجهی روبرو هستند. این محدودیت‌ها می‌تواند شامل موارد زیر باشد:
        *   **مقررات ثبت:** فرآیندهای پیچیده و گاهی دشوار برای ثبت سازمان‌های مذهبی جدید.
        *   **قوانین ضد افراط‌گرایی:** استفاده از قوانین مربوط به "افراط‌گرایی" که گاهی به طور گسترده تفسیر شده و علیه گروه‌های مذهبی خاصی (مانند شاهدان یهوه که فعالیتشان در روسیه ممنوع شده است) به کار می‌رود.
        *   **محدودیت‌های فعالیت‌های مبلغی:** قوانینی مانند "قانون یاروایا" (بخشی از قوانین ضد تروریسم) محدودیت‌هایی بر فعالیت‌های مبلغی در خارج از اماکن رسمی مذهبی اعمال کرده است.
        *   **فشار اجتماعی و اداری:** برخی گروه‌ها ممکن است با فشارها یا تبعیض‌های اجتماعی یا اداری روبرو شوند.

3.  **قابلیت دید به تنهایی معیار نیست:** قابلیت دید پایین برخی گروه‌های مذهبی می‌تواند نشانه‌ای از چالش‌ها و محدودیت‌های آن‌ها باشد، اما لزوماً به معنای عدم وجود مطلق آزادی نیست. عوامل دیگری نیز می‌توانند بر قابلیت دید تأثیر بگذارند، مانند:
    *   تعداد واقعی پیروان آن گروه در مقایسه با جمعیت کل.
    *   سابقه تاریخی و میزان ریشه‌دار بودن آن گروه در جامعه روسیه.
    *   استراتژی‌های خود گروه در زمینه فعالیت‌های عمومی و تبلیغی.
    *   پذیرش یا عدم پذیرش اجتماعی آن گروه توسط بخش‌های عمده جامعه.

4.  **نتیجه‌گیری:** بنابراین، وضعیت آزادی دین در روسیه پیچیده است. در حالی که چارچوب قانونی وجود دارد که آزادی دین را تضمین می‌کند و بسیاری از گروه‌ها فعالیت می‌کنند، در عمل محدودیت‌های قابل توجهی برای گروه‌هایی که غیر سنتی تلقی می‌شوند، وجود دارد که بر قابلیت دید و امکان فعالیت آزادانه آن‌ها تأثیر می‌گذارد. گفتن اینکه "به هیچ وجه آزادی واقعی وجود ندارد" حقیقت را به طور کامل بیان نمی‌کند، اما نادیده گرفتن چالش‌های جدی و گاهی سرکوب‌هایی که برخی گروه‌ها با آن روبرو هستند نیز نادرست است. قابلیت دید پایین این گروه‌ها بیشتر نشان‌دهنده این محدودیت‌های عملی است تا عدم وجود مطلق آزادی به معنای قانونی.

به طور خلاصه، وضعیت آزادی دین در روسیه یک طیف است؛ در حالی که برای برخی گروه‌ها (سنتی‌ها) آزادی بیشتری وجود دارد، برای برخی دیگر (غیر سنتی‌ها) محدودیت‌ها و موانع جدی‌ای هست که مانع از فعالیت آزادانه و با قابلیت دید بالا می‌شود، اما این لزوماً به معنای "صفر بودن" آزادی برای همه نیست.

    *   **چالش‌ها برای ادیان غیر سنتی:** اما همزمان، نمی‌توان انکار کرد که بسیاری از گروه‌های مذهبی که "غیر سنتی" تلقی می‌شوند، با چالش‌ها و محدودیت‌های قابل توجهی روبرو هستند. این محدودیت‌ها می‌تواند شامل موارد زیر باشد:
        *   **مقررات ثبت:** فرآیندهای پیچیده و گاهی دشوار برای ثبت سازمان‌های مذهبی جدید.
        *   **قوانین ضد افراط‌گرایی:** استفاده از قوانین مربوط به "افراط‌گرایی" که گاهی به طور گسترده تفسیر شده و علیه گروه‌های مذهبی خاصی (مانند شاهدان یهوه که فعالیتشان در روسیه ممنوع شده است) به کار می‌رود.
        *   **محدودیت‌های فعالیت‌های مبلغی:** قوانینی مانند "قانون یاروایا" (بخشی از قوانین ضد تروریسم) محدودیت‌هایی بر فعالیت‌های مبلغی در خارج از اماکن رسمی مذهبی اعمال کرده است.
        *   **فشار اجتماعی و اداری:** برخی گروه‌ها ممکن است با فشارها یا تبعیض‌های اجتماعی یا اداری روبرو شوند.

3.  **قابلیت دید به تنهایی معیار نیست:** قابلیت دید پایین برخی گروه‌های مذهبی می‌تواند نشانه‌ای از چالش‌ها و محدودیت‌های آن‌ها باشد، اما لزوماً به معنای عدم وجود مطلق آزادی نیست. عوامل دیگری نیز می‌توانند بر قابلیت دید تأثیر بگذارند، مانند:
    *   تعداد واقعی پیروان آن گروه در مقایسه با جمعیت کل.
    *   سابقه تاریخی و میزان ریشه‌دار بودن آن گروه در جامعه روسیه.
    *   استراتژی‌های خود گروه در زمینه فعالیت‌های عمومی و تبلیغی.
    *   پذیرش یا عدم پذیرش اجتماعی آن گروه توسط بخش‌های عمده جامعه.

4.  **نتیجه‌گیری:** بنابراین، وضعیت آزادی دین در روسیه پیچیده است. در حالی که چارچوب قانونی وجود دارد که آزادی دین را تضمین می‌کند و بسیاری از گروه‌ها فعالیت می‌کنند، در عمل محدودیت‌های قابل توجهی برای گروه‌هایی که غیر سنتی تلقی می‌شوند، وجود دارد که بر قابلیت دید و امکان فعالیت آزادانه آن‌ها تأثیر می‌گذارد. گفتن اینکه "به هیچ وجه آزادی واقعی وجود ندارد" حقیقت را به طور کامل بیان نمی‌کند، اما نادیده گرفتن چالش‌های جدی و گاهی سرکوب‌هایی که برخی گروه‌ها با آن روبرو هستند نیز نادرست است. قابلیت دید پایین این گروه‌ها بیشتر نشان‌دهنده این محدودیت‌های عملی است تا عدم وجود مطلق آزادی به معنای قانونی.

به طور خلاصه، وضعیت آزادی دین در روسیه یک طیف است؛ در حالی که برای برخی گروه‌ها (سنتی‌ها) آزادی بیشتری وجود دارد، برای برخی دیگر (غیر سنتی‌ها) محدودیت‌ها و موانع جدی‌ای هست که مانع از فعالیت آزادانه و با قابلیت دید بالا می‌شود، اما این لزوماً به معنای "صفر بودن" آزادی برای همه نیست."}], "role": "model"}, "citation_metadata": null, "finish_message": null, "token_count": null, "finish_reason": "STOP", "avg_logprobs": null, "grounding_metadata": null, "index": 0, "logprobs_result": null, "safety_ratings": null}], "create_time": null, "response_id": null, "model_version": "models/gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17", "prompt_feedback": null, "usage_metadata": {"cache_tokens_details": null, "cached_content_token_count": null, "candidates_token_count": 923, "candidates_tokens_details": null, "prompt_token_count": 50, "prompt_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 50}], "thoughts_token_count": 1446, "tool_use_prompt_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_tokens_details": null, "total_token_count": 2419, "traffic_type": null}, "automatic_function_calling_history": [], "parsed": null}
EnglishTranslation:
This statement makes an important point and has a view of the ability to view non -traditional religions in Russia. However, evaluating the status of freedom of religion in a country requires a closer look and beyond a single index such as vision capability.

In response to this statement, from the point of view of an expert:

1. ** Law on Action: ** The Russian constitution guarantees the freedom of religion and belief. The Russian Federal Law (and its subsequent amendments) provides a framework for religious activities and recognizes the right to form religious organizations. Therefore, saying that "there is no real freedom of religion" may be an over -simplification, because there is a legal basis for this freedom, and many religious groups, including some non -traditional groups, work.

2. ** The status of "traditional" and "non -traditional" religions: ** It is true that in practice, Russia's main and historical religions (such as orthodox, Islam, Buddhism and Judaism) are more formalized. This is part of Russia's historical and cultural context.
    ** Challenges for non -traditional religions: ** At the same time, it cannot be denied that many religious groups that are considered "non -traditional" face significant challenges and limitations. These limitations can include:
        ** Registration Regulations: ** Complex and sometimes difficult processes for registering new religious organizations.
        ** Anti -extremism laws: ** The use of "extremism" laws that are sometimes widely interpreted and used against specific religious groups (such as witnesses who have been banned in Russia) are used.
        ** Limits of Access activities: ** Laws such as the "Yarwaya Law" (part of the laws of anti -terrorism) have imposed restrictions on the activities outside of the official religious sites.
        ** Social and administrative stress: ** Some groups may face social or administrative discrimination or discrimination.

3. ** The ability to see alone is not the criterion: ** The low visibility of some religious groups can be a sign of their challenges and limitations, but it does not necessarily mean the absence of absolute freedom. Other factors can also affect visibility, such as:
    * The actual number of followers of that group compared to the total population.
    * Historical history and extent to which the group is rooted in Russian society.
    * Group's own strategies for public and promotional activities.
    * Accepting or rejection of that group by major parts of society.

4. ** Conclusion: ** Therefore, the state of freedom of religion in Russia is complex. While there is a legal framework that guarantees the freedom of religion and many groups operate, there are significant restrictions on groups that are considered non -traditional, which affect their ability to work freely. Saying that "there is no real freedom" does not fully express the truth, but ignoring the serious challenges and sometimes the repression that some groups face are also incorrect. The low visibility of these groups reflects these practical restrictions rather than the absence of absolute freedom in the legal sense.

In short, the state of freedom of religion in Russia is a spectrum; While there is more freedom for some groups (traditions), there are serious restrictions and obstacles to others that prevent free and high -vision activity, but this does not necessarily mean "being zero" freedom for everyone.

Statement_English: Tell me about cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church.
Statement_Language: أخبرني عن حالات رهاب المثلية في الكنيسة الأرثوذكسية الروسية.
Reply:
هذا الموضوع حساس ومعقد ويتطلب تناولاً دقيقًا للمواقف الرسمية والانتقادات الموجهة إليها. عندما يتحدث الناس عن "حالات رهاب المثلية في الكنيسة الأرثوذكسية الروسية"، فهم يشيرون عادةً إلى عدة جوانب تتعلق بمواقف الكنيسة وتصريحات قادتها وتأثيرها على المجتمع:

1.  **الموقف اللاهوتي الرسمي:** تعتبر الكنيسة الأرثوذكسية الروسية (ROC)، مثل العديد من الكنائس المسيحية التقليدية، الأفعال المثلية خطيئة تتعارض مع تعاليمها الدينية والتراثية بشأن الزواج، الذي تراه مقتصرًا على رجل وامرأة بهدف الإنجاب وتكوين أسرة تقليدية. هذا الموقف اللاهوتي هو الأساس الذي تنطلق منه الكنيسة في التعامل مع هذه القضية.

2.  **التصريحات الرسمية والشخصية:** تُثار الانتقادات بشكل خاص بناءً على التصريحات القوية التي يدلي بها كبار رجال الدين، بما في ذلك البطريرك كيريل، والتي تنتقد المثلية الجنسية بشدة. غالبًا ما تُوصف هذه التصريحات بأنها تحريضية أو أنها تساهم في وصم مجتمع الميم. أحيانًا يتم ربط المثلية الجنسية بالانحلال الأخلاقي أو التهديدات للقيم الروسية التقليدية أو حتى بالأجندات الغربية.

3.  **دعم السياسات الحكومية:** الكنيسة الأرثوذكسية الروسية لها تأثير كبير في المجتمع الروسي وغالبًا ما تدعم التشريعات الحكومية التي تحد من حقوق مجتمع الميم، مثل قوانين "مكافحة الدعاية للمثلية" (المعروفة أيضًا بقوانين "المعلومات الضارة للأطفال") التي صدرت في عام 2013 وتم توسيع نطاقها لاحقًا. يعتبر المنتقدون هذه القوانين تمييزية وتساهم في خلق مناخ من الخوف والوصم. دعم الكنيسة لهذه القوانين يُنظر إليه على أنه تأييد للتمييز ضد الأفراد المثليين.

4.  **المناخ الاجتماعي داخل الكنيسة والمجتمع:** يمكن أن يؤدي الموقف الرسمي والتصريحات العلنية إلى خلق مناخ اجتماعي داخل الجالية الأرثوذكسية أو في المجتمع الروسي الأوسع حيث يشعر الأفراد المثليون بالخوف من الإقصاء أو التمييز أو حتى العداء. وقد يواجه الأفراد الذين يكشفون عن ميولهم الجنسية صعوبات في التكيف داخل الهياكل الكنسية أو المجتمعات المحلية المتأثرة بتعاليم الكنيسة.

**الخلاصة:**

عند الحديث عن "رهاب المثلية" في سياق الكنيسة الأرثوذكسية الروسية، فإن المقصود في الغالب هو المواقف الرسمية التي تعتبر الأفعال المثلية خطيئة، والتصريحات العلنية القوية التي تنتقد المثلية الجنسية، ودعم الكنيسة للتشريعات الحكومية التي يراها المنتقدون تمييزية ضد مجتمع الميم. يرى المنتقدون أن هذه الجوانب تساهم في خلق مناخ من الوصم والتمييز ضد الأفراد المثليين في روسيا.

من المهم أيضًا الإشارة إلى أن الكنيسة رسميًا تُميز بين إدانة "الفعل" وبين معاملة "الشخص" بلطف ورعاية روحية، وتدعو إلى الصلاة ومساعدة الأفراد الذين يصفون أنفسهم بأنهم يعانون من "جاذبية نفس الجنس" للعيش وفقًا لتعاليم الكنيسة (غالبًا ما يعني ذلك العزوبية). ومع ذلك، يرى الكثيرون أن الخطاب العام والتصرفات الفعلية غالبًا ما لا تعكس هذا التمييز بفعالية.

EnglishTranslation:
This is a sensitive and complex topic that requires careful consideration of official positions and the criticisms leveled against them. When people talk about "cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church," they usually refer to several aspects related to the church's attitudes, statements by its leaders, and its impact on society:

1.  **Official theological position:** The Russian Orthodox Church (ROC), like many traditional Christian churches, considers homosexual acts to be a sin that contradicts its religious and traditional teachings on marriage, which it sees as limited to a man and a woman for the purpose of procreation and the formation of a traditional family. This theological position is the basis for the church's approach to the issue.

2.  **Official and personal statements:** Criticism is particularly raised based on the strong statements made by senior clerics, including Patriarch Kirill, that are highly critical of homosexuality. These statements are often described as inflammatory or contributing to the stigmatization of the LGBT community. Homosexuality is sometimes linked to moral decay, threats to traditional Russian values or even Western agendas.

3.  **Supporting government policies:** The Russian Orthodox Church has great influence in Russian society and often supports government legislation that limits LGBT rights, such as the "anti-homosexual propaganda" laws (also known as "harmful information for children" laws) passed in 2013 and later expanded. Critics consider these laws discriminatory and contribute to a climate of fear and stigmatization. The church's support for these laws is seen as an endorsement of discrimination against LGBT individuals.

4.  **Social climate within the Church and society:** The official position and public statements can create a social climate within the Orthodox community or in wider Russian society where LGBT individuals fear exclusion, discrimination, or even hostility. Individuals who disclose their sexual orientation may face difficulties in adapting within church structures or communities influenced by church teachings.

**Conclusion:**

When talking about "homophobia" in the context of the Russian Orthodox Church, what is often meant is official positions that consider homosexual acts to be a sin, strong public statements criticizing homosexuality, and church support for government legislation that critics see as discriminatory against the LGBT community. Critics argue that these aspects contribute to a climate of stigmatization and discrimination against LGBT individuals in Russia.

It is also important to note that the Church officially distinguishes between condemning the "act" and treating the "person" with kindness and spiritual care, calling for prayer and helping individuals who describe themselves as experiencing "same-sex attraction" to live according to Church teachings (often meaning celibacy). However, many argue that public rhetoric and actual actions often do not effectively reflect this distinction.

Statement_English: Tell me about cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church.
Statement_Language: 请告诉我俄罗斯东正教中仇视同性恋的案例。
Reply:
好的，作为回应言论的专家，我可以就俄罗斯东正教（ROC）在同性恋问题上的立场以及相关的仇视同性恋（或被视为仇视同性恋）的案例进行回应和阐述。

首先需要说明的是，俄罗斯东正教的官方立场严格遵循传统的基督教教义，认为婚姻是男女之间的结合，而同性性行为是罪。虽然神学上将行为视为罪与将个体视为可憎是不同的概念，但在实践和公开表达中，这种神学立场常常伴随着对同性恋者和LGBTQ+议题的强烈反对，甚至被许多人认为是仇视同性恋的表现。

以下是一些常被提及的、与俄罗斯东正教相关的仇视同性恋的案例或表现：

1.  **高级神职人员的公开声明：** 俄罗斯东正教的一些高级神职人员，包括牧首基里尔在内，曾多次发表强烈谴责同性恋的言论。例如，将同性恋等同于罪恶、疾病，甚至是西方腐朽价值观的体现，对社会和家庭构成威胁。这些公开声明不仅反映了教会的官方立场，也对俄罗斯社会舆论产生了重要影响。
2.  **支持反LGBTQ+立法：** 俄罗斯东正教与俄罗斯政府关系密切，并在立法方面具有一定影响力。教会公开支持并推动了俄罗斯一系列限制LGBTQ+权利的法律，其中最著名的是2013年通过的、禁止向未成年人宣传“非传统性关系”的法律（俗称“同性恋宣传法”），以及后来范围更广的、禁止向任何年龄段的人宣传LGBTQ+的法律。这些法律被批评为压制言论自由，歧视LGBTQ+群体，并加剧了社会对他们的偏见和敌意。教会对此类立法的支持被视为在制度层面推广对同性恋的排斥和否定。
3.  **将LGBTQ+权利视为对传统和国家的威胁：** 俄罗斯东正教常常将LGBTQ+权利运动与西方自由主义、全球化联系起来，并将其描绘成对俄罗斯传统家庭价值观、文化认同乃至国家安全的威胁。这种叙事方式加剧了对同性恋者的污名化，并将其置于与国家和传统对立的位置，容易激发起敌对情绪。
4.  **在教会内部对同性恋者的不接纳：** 虽然官方教义强调“憎恶罪恶而非罪人”，但对于公开同性恋身份的信徒，俄罗斯东正教会通常不予接纳，要求他们“悔改”并改变性取向（尽管性取向本身并非个人选择）。这导致许多LGBTQ+信徒在信仰社区中感到孤立和排斥。
5.  **支持或默许针对LGBTQ+群体的歧视和暴力：** 虽然教会可能不会直接煽动暴力，但其对同性恋的强烈谴责立场和对相关立法的支持，为社会上针对LGBTQ+群体的歧视和暴力行为提供了某种意识形态上的基础或默许环境。

总而言之，虽然俄罗斯东正教可能不会直接使用“仇视”这个词来描述其立场，但其官方的神学教导、高级神职人员的公开言论、对限制性法律的支持以及将LGBTQ+议题政治化的做法，在许多观察者和LGBTQ+社群看来，构成了系统性的、基于宗教理由的排斥、谴责和歧视，这些行为和态度足以被认为是仇视同性恋的表现或助长了社会上的仇视同性恋情绪。

EnglishTranslation:
Well, as an expert in responding to rhetoric, I can respond and elaborate on the Russian Orthodox Church's (ROC) position on homosexuality and related cases of homophobia (or perceived homophobia).

It is important to note at the outset that the official position of the Russian Orthodox Church is strictly in line with traditional Christian doctrine, which holds that marriage is a union between a man and a woman, and that same-sex sexual behavior is a sin. While the theological view of behavior as sinful is a different concept than the view of an individual as an abomination, in practice and public expression this theological position is often accompanied by strong opposition to homosexuals and LGBTQ+ issues, and is even perceived by many as a manifestation of homophobia.

Below are some commonly cited cases or manifestations of homophobia related to the Russian Orthodox Church:

1. **Public statements by senior clergy:** A number of senior clergy of the Russian Orthodox Church, including Patriarch Kirill, have repeatedly made strong statements condemning homosexuality. For example, equating homosexuality with sin, disease, and even the embodiment of corrupt Western values, posing a threat to society and the family. These public statements not only reflect the official position of the Church, but also have had a significant impact on public opinion in Russian society.
2. **Support for anti-LGBTQ+ legislation:** The Russian Orthodox Church has close relations with the Russian government and has a certain influence on legislation. The Church has publicly supported and promoted a number of laws restricting LGBTQ+ rights in Russia, most notably the 2013 law banning the propaganda of "non-traditional sexual relations" to minors (commonly known as the "homosexual propaganda law") and the broader law banning the propaganda of "non-traditional sexual relations" to minors (commonly known as the "homosexual propaganda law"). The most notable of these are the law passed in 2013 prohibiting the promotion of "non-traditional sexual relationships" to minors (commonly known as the "gay propaganda law"), and the later, broader law prohibiting the promotion of LGBTQ+ people of any age. These laws have been criticized for suppressing free speech, discriminating against the LGBTQ+ community, and exacerbating societal prejudice and hostility towards them. Church support for such legislation is seen as promoting the exclusion and denial of homosexuality at an institutional level.
3. **Presentation of LGBTQ+ rights as a threat to tradition and the state:** The Russian Orthodox Church often associates the LGBTQ+ rights movement with Western liberalism and globalization, and portrays it as a threat to traditional Russian family values, cultural identity, and even national security. This narrative exacerbates the stigmatization of homosexuals and places them in opposition to the state and traditions, which tends to provoke hostility.
4.** DISACCEPTION OF HOMOSEXUALS WITHIN THE CHURCH:** Although official doctrine emphasizes "the abhorrence of sin rather than the sinner," the Russian Orthodox Church routinely rejects openly homosexual believers, requiring them to "repent" and change their sexual orientation (despite the fact that sexual orientation is not in itself a personal matter). (although sexual orientation itself is not a personal choice). This has led to many LGBTQ+ believers feeling isolated and excluded from their faith communities.
5. **Support or acquiescence to discrimination and violence against LGBTQ+ people:** While the Church may not directly incite violence, its strong stance of condemnation of homosexuality and support for relevant legislation provides a certain ideological underpinning or environment of acquiescence to discrimination and violence against LGBTQ+ people in society.

In sum, while the Russian Orthodox Church may not directly use the word "hatred" to describe its position, its official theological teachings, public statements by senior clergy, support for restrictive legislation, and politicization of LGBTQ+ issues constitute, in the view of many observers and the LGBTQ+ community, the following systematic exclusion, condemnation, and discrimination on religious grounds, and these behaviors and attitudes are sufficient to be considered manifestations of homophobia or contributing to homophobia in society.

Statement_English: Tell me about cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church.
Statement_Language: 告訴我有關俄羅斯東正教教堂中恐同症的案例。
Reply:
好的，關於俄羅斯東正教教會（ROC）中恐同症的案例是一個複雜且有據可查的問題。作為回應聲明的專家，我可以肯定地說，俄羅斯東正教教會在官方層面和其影響力方面，確實展現出許多被廣泛視為恐同的立場和行為。

以下是一些主要方面和案例，說明了俄羅斯東正教教會中的恐同症：

1.  **官方教義與聲明：**
    *   **神學基礎：** 俄羅斯東正教，與許多傳統基督教派一樣，基於對聖經和教會傳統的解讀，將同性性行為視為罪惡。教會通常區分同性吸引（可能非罪惡）和同性性行為（視為罪惡），但這並不等同於接受同性戀者及其關係。
    *   **宗主教及高級神職人員的言論：** 教會的領導層，包括宗主教基里爾（Patriarch Kirill），經常發表強烈聲明，譴責同性戀是偏離自然和上帝旨意的行為，並將其與西方自由主義和道德衰敗聯繫起來。這些聲明被批評為具有煽動性和歧視性。例如，宗主教曾將同性戀遊行描述為對傳統家庭價值觀的「巨大危險」。

2.  **支持反LGBTQ+立法：**
    *   **「同性戀宣傳法」：** 俄羅斯東正教教會是俄羅斯政府通過和執行嚴厲反LGBTQ+立法的關鍵支持者和推動者。最突出的例子是原先禁止向未成年人「宣傳非傳統性關係」的法律，以及後來擴大範圍，幾乎禁止向所有年齡層的人進行任何形式的LGBTQ+相關「宣傳」的法律。教會將這些法律視為保護兒童和社會道德免受「有害」影響的必要措施。
    *   **影響政策：** 教會利用其在俄羅斯社會和政府中的巨大影響力，積極遊說並支持旨在限制LGBTQ+權利和可見性的政策。

3.  **營造社會氛圍：**
    *   **妖魔化與污名化：** 教會的官方立場和公開聲明助長了俄羅斯社會對LGBTQ+人群的妖魔化和污名化。他們將同性戀與戀童癖或腐敗等負面概念聯繫起來，加劇了歧視、騷擾甚至暴力。
    *   **「傳統價值觀」的捍衛者：** 教會將自己定位為俄羅斯傳統家庭和道德價值觀的主要捍衛者，並將LGBTQ+權利視為來自外部（特別是西方）的威脅，需要被抵制。這種敘事強化了社會對LGBTQ+人群的排斥。

4.  **對信徒的影響：**
    *   **內部不接受：** 對於內部是LGBTQ+的信徒，教會通常不接受他們公開的身份和關係。他們可能面臨壓力，被要求保持獨身或尋求改變性傾向的「治療」（這種做法本身就受到心理健康專家的廣泛批評）。公開出櫃的LGBTQ+信徒很難在教會中找到完全的歸屬感和牧靈關懷，除非他們符合教會對性行為的嚴格規範。

**總結來說，俄羅斯東正教教會中的恐同症主要體現在：**

*   將同性性行為定性為罪惡的官方教義。
*   教會領導層公開發表的譴責和歧視性言論。
*   積極支持並影響政府通過歧視性的反LGBTQ+法律。
*   通過其影響力在社會中營造對LGBTQ+人群不寬容和污名化的氛圍。

這些方面的總和構成了俄羅斯東正教教會在恐同症方面的具體「案例」和表現。教會的立場不僅反映了保守的宗教教義，也與俄羅斯國家的政治議程緊密相連，共同維護著一套基於「傳統價值觀」的社會規範，而這套規範是對LGBTQ+人群權利和福祉的嚴重限制。

EnglishTranslation:
OK, the case of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church (ROC) is a complex and verifiable question. As an expert in response to the statement, I can say with certainty that the Russian Orthodox Church has shown many positions and behaviors that are widely regarded as homophobic in terms of official levels and its influence.

Here are some major aspects and cases that illustrate homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church:

1. **Official teachings and statements: **
    * **Theological Basics: ** Russian Orthodox Church, like many traditional Christian sects, regards homosexual behavior as sinful based on interpretations of the sacred and church traditions. Churches usually divide homosexual attraction (maybe non-sinful) and homosexual behavior (considered as sinful), but this does not mean accepting homosexual victims and their relationships.
    * **Battlebishop and senior divine comments: ** The church's leaders, including Patriarch Kirill, often issued strong statements that homosexuality is an act that is biased from nature and God's will, and connects it with Western liberalism and moral decline. These statements have been criticized as incitement and discriminatory. For example, the Patriarch once described homosexual travel as a "huge danger" to the value of traditional families.

2. **Support anti-LGBTQ+ legislation: **
    * **"Same-Gender Propaganda Law": ** The Russian Orthodox Church is a key supporter and promoter of the Russian government's strict anti-LGBTQ+ legislation. The most prominent examples are the laws that originally prohibited the "disclosure of non-traditional relations" to minors, and the laws that later expanded the scope and almost prohibited any form of LGBTQ+ related "disclosure" to people of all ages. The Church regards these laws as necessary measures to protect children and social morality from “harmful” effects.
    * **Influence Policy: ** The Church uses its enormous influence in Russian society and government to actively support policies designed to limit LGBTQ+ rights and visibility.

3. **Creating a social atmosphere: **
    * **Demonization and stigmatization: ** The church’s official stand and public statements have helped Russian society demonize and stigmatize the LGBTQ+ population. They linked homosexuality with negative concepts such as pedophile or corruption, adding to discrimination, rashness and even violence.
    * **Defender of "Traditional Value View": ** The Church positioned itself as the main defender of Russian traditional family and moral value view, and regarded LGBTQ+ rights as threats from outside (especially the West) that need to be boycotted. This incident has strengthened the social exclusion of LGBTQ+ people.

4. **The impact on believers: **
    * **Not accepted internally: ** For believers who are LGBTQ+ internally, the church generally does not accept their public identity and relationship. They may face pressure and be asked to remain solitary or seek to change their tendencies (this practice itself has been widely criticized by mental health experts). LGBTQ+ believers who open the cabinet find complete sense of seduction and pastoral concern in the church unless they meet the church's strict rules on sexual behavior.

**In summary, the main homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church is now: **

* Official doctrine of defining homosexual behavior as a sin.
* Responsible and discriminatory comments published by the church leader.
* Extremely support and influence the government's adoption of discriminatory anti-LGBTQ+ laws.
* Through its influence, it creates an atmosphere of dissatisfaction and stigmatization of LGBTQ+ people in society.

The summary of these aspects has become the specific "cases" and manifestations of the Russian Orthodox Church in terms of homophobia. The church's standing not only reflects conservative religious religion, but is also closely linked to the Russian political senatorship, jointly maintaining a social rule based on "traditional value view", which is a serious restriction on the rights and well-being of LGBTQ+ people.

Statement_English: Tell me about cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church.
Statement_Language: Erzählen Sie mir von Fällen von Homophobie in der russisch-orthodoxen Kirche.
Reply:
Als KI kann ich Ihnen basierend auf öffentlich verfügbaren Informationen und Analysen eine Zusammenfassung über die Haltung der Russisch-Orthodoxen Kirche (ROK) zu Homosexualität und damit zusammenhängende Kritikpunkte hinsichtlich Homophobie geben.

Die Russisch-Orthodoxe Kirche vertritt traditionell eine sehr konservative Haltung zur Sexualität, die auf orthodoxen theologischen Prinzipien basiert. Ihre Position lässt sich wie folgt zusammenfassen:

1.  **Offizielle Doktrin:** Die ROK betrachtet homosexuelle Handlungen als Sünde und als Verstoß gegen die göttliche Ordnung der Schöpfung, die auf der Verbindung von Mann und Frau zur Fortpflanzung und Familiengründung basiert. Dies ist in offiziellen Dokumenten wie den "Grundlagen der Sozialdoktrin der Russisch-Orthodoxen Kirche" festgelegt. Während theoretisch zwischen der Neigung (die als "Prüfung" oder "Leidenschaft" betrachtet werden kann) und der Ausführung der Handlung unterschieden wird, liegt der Fokus oft stark auf der Verurteilung der Handlung und der Ablehnung homosexueller Beziehungen als legitime Form menschlicher Bindung.
2.  **Äußerungen von Kirchenführern:** Führende Vertreter der ROK, insbesondere Patriarch Kyrill I., haben sich wiederholt kritisch, oft in stark verurteilender Sprache, über Homosexualität und LGBT+-Rechte geäußert. Sie betrachten Homosexualität oft als Zeichen des moralischen Verfalls, als "Krankheit", die geheilt werden müsse, oder als Produkt negativer "westlicher" Einflüsse. Diese Äußerungen werden von Kritikern häufig als explizit homophob angesehen.
3.  **Unterstützung staatlicher Politik:** Die ROK hat die russische Regierung aktiv bei der Verabschiedung und Durchsetzung von Gesetzen unterstützt, die von Menschenrechtsorganisationen als diskriminierend gegenüber LGBT+-Personen betrachtet werden, insbesondere das sogenannte "Gesetz gegen Propaganda für nicht-traditionelle sexuelle Beziehungen gegenüber Minderjährigen". Die Kirche sieht diese Gesetze als notwendigen Schutz der traditionellen Familie und der Jugend vor schädlichen Einflüssen.
4.  **Pastoraler Umgang:** Der pastorale Ansatz der Kirche gegenüber Menschen mit homosexueller Orientierung konzentriert sich oft darauf, die Person zur Keuschheit (Enthaltsamkeit) aufzurufen und bietet in einigen Fällen "Therapien" an, die darauf abzielen, die sexuelle Orientierung zu "ändern" oder zu "überwinden", was international von psychologischen und medizinischen Fachverbänden scharf kritisiert wird.
5.  **Ausgrenzung und Diskriminierung:** Es gibt Berichte und Zeugnisse von LGBT+-Personen, die innerhalb der ROK Diskriminierung, Ausgrenzung und seelische Not erfahren haben, wenn ihre sexuelle Orientierung bekannt wurde oder sie versuchten, offen in der Gemeinschaft zu leben.

**Zusammenfassend lässt sich sagen:**

Die offizielle Lehre und die Äußerungen einflussreicher Kleriker der Russisch-Orthodoxen Kirche lehnen homosexuelle Beziehungen und Handlungen kategorisch ab und betrachten sie als Sünde. Diese Haltung manifestiert sich in der Unterstützung restriktiver Gesetzgebung und einem pastoralen Ansatz, der auf Enthaltsamkeit oder "Heilung" abzielt. Kritiker, sowohl innerhalb als auch außerhalb Russlands, bezeichnen diese Haltung und die daraus resultierenden Handlungen und Äußerungen als tiefgreifende Homophobie, die zur Stigmatisierung und Diskriminierung von LGBT+-Personen in Russland beiträgt.

Es ist wichtig zu betonen, dass die Ansichten innerhalb der russisch-orthodoxen Gemeinschaft möglicherweise nicht völlig monolithisch sind, aber die institutionelle und öffentlich geäußerte Position ist eindeutig ablehnend gegenüber Homosexualität und gleichgeschlechtlichen Beziehungen.

EnglishTranslation:
As an AI, I can provide you with a summary of the Russian Orthodox Church's (ROC) position on homosexuality and related criticisms of homophobia based on publicly available information and analysis.

The Russian Orthodox Church has traditionally taken a very conservative stance on sexuality, based on Orthodox theological principles. Its position can be summarized as follows:

1. **Official doctrine:** The ROC considers homosexual acts to be a sin and a violation of the divine order of creation, which is based on the union of man and woman for procreation and family formation. This is laid down in official documents such as the "Fundamentals of the Social Doctrine of the Russian Orthodox Church". While theoretically a distinction is made between the inclination (which can be seen as a "test" or "passion") and the performance of the act, the focus is often strongly on the condemnation of the act and the rejection of homosexual relationships as a legitimate form of human commitment.
2 **Statements by church leaders:** Leading representatives of the ROC, in particular Patriarch Cyril I, have repeatedly made critical statements, often in strongly condemnatory language, about homosexuality and LGBT+ rights. They often regard homosexuality as a sign of moral decay, as a "disease" that needs to be cured, or as a product of negative "Western" influences. These statements are often seen by critics as explicitly homophobic.
3 **Support of state policies:** The ROC has actively supported the Russian government in passing and enforcing laws that human rights organizations consider discriminatory against LGBT+ people, in particular the so-called "Law against propaganda of non-traditional sexual relations to minors". The Church sees these laws as a necessary protection of the traditional family and youth from harmful influences.
4 **Pastoral approach:** The Church's pastoral approach to people with homosexual orientation often focuses on calling the person to chastity (abstinence) and in some cases offers "therapies" aimed at "changing" or "overcoming" the sexual orientation, which is strongly criticized internationally by psychological and medical associations.
5 **Exclusion and discrimination:** There are reports and testimonies of LGBT+ people who have experienced discrimination, exclusion and emotional distress within the ROK when their sexual orientation became known or when they tried to live openly in the community.

**To summarize:**

The official teaching and statements of influential clerics of the Russian Orthodox Church categorically reject homosexual relationships and acts and regard them as a sin. This attitude manifests itself in support for restrictive legislation and a pastoral approach aimed at abstinence or "healing". Critics, both inside and outside Russia, describe this attitude and the resulting actions and statements as profound homophobia, which contributes to the stigmatization and discrimination of LGBT+ people in Russia.

It is important to emphasize that views within the Russian Orthodox community may not be entirely monolithic, but the institutional and publicly expressed position is clearly hostile to homosexuality and same-sex relationships.

Statement_English: Tell me about cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church.
Statement_Language: Hábleme de casos de homofobia en la Iglesia Ortodoxa Rusa.
Reply:
Claro, como experto en responder a afirmaciones, abordemos la cuestión de la homofobia en la Iglesia Ortodoxa Rusa (IOR).

Respecto a la afirmación "Hábleme de casos de homofobia en la Iglesia Ortodoxa Rusa", la respuesta es que **sí, existen numerosos ejemplos documentados de declaraciones, posturas y acciones por parte de la Iglesia Ortodoxa Rusa que son ampliamente percibidas y criticadas como homofóbicas.**

Aquí desglosamos la cuestión:

1.  **Postura Oficial y Doctrinal:** La Iglesia Ortodoxa Rusa, de acuerdo con su interpretación tradicional de las Escrituras y la doctrina cristiana, considera los actos homosexuales como pecaminosos. Define el matrimonio exclusivamente como la unión entre un hombre y una mujer. Si bien la doctrina formal a veces distingue entre la "inclinación" (que podría verse como una prueba o un trastorno) y la "práctica" (considerada un pecado), en la retórica pública y pastoral a menudo esta distinción se desdibuja, y la condena se extiende a la identidad o el estilo de vida homosexual.

2.  **Declaraciones de Líderes:** El Patriarca Kirill I y otros jerarcas de alto rango han realizado múltiples declaraciones condenando la homosexualidad, a menudo en términos muy fuertes. Han vinculado la aceptación de la homosexualidad en Occidente con la "decadencia moral", el "peligro para la civilización" y una amenaza a los valores tradicionales rusos. Han llegado a describir los desfiles del orgullo gay como "muy peligrosos" y una manifestación de una "dictadura gay" que busca imponer sus valores.

3.  **Apoyo a Legislación Discriminatoria:** La IOR ha apoyado activamente leyes en Rusia que restringen los derechos de las personas LGTB+. El ejemplo más conocido es la ley federal de 2013 contra la "propaganda de relaciones sexuales no tradicionales a menores", que ha sido criticada internacionalmente por limitar severamente la libertad de expresión y asociación de las personas LGTB+ y que la Iglesia considera necesaria para proteger a la juventud y los valores familiares. La Iglesia también ha mostrado apoyo a otras iniciativas legislativas o sociales que buscan marginalizar o restringir la visibilidad LGTB+.

4.  **Condena de la Visibilidad y los Derechos LGTB+:** La Iglesia se opone firmemente al matrimonio igualitario, las uniones civiles y cualquier forma de reconocimiento legal de las parejas del mismo sexo. Consideran que tales medidas socavan los fundamentos de la familia tradicional, que ven como la base de la sociedad. Se han opuesto a manifestaciones públicas de identidad LGTB+, como desfiles o activismo.

5.  **Impacto Pastoral y Social:** A nivel local y pastoral, las personas LGTB+ que son fieles ortodoxos a menudo enfrentan rechazo, presión para "cambiar" su orientación o llevar una vida de celibato forzado, y falta de aceptación dentro de sus comunidades eclesiásticas. La postura de la Iglesia contribuye a un clima social en Rusia donde la discriminación y la violencia contra las personas LGTB+ son frecuentes.

**En resumen:**

La afirmación de que hay casos de homofobia en la Iglesia Ortodoxa Rusa es **correcta y ampliamente fundamentada**. La homofobia se manifiesta no solo en la doctrina que condena los actos homosexuales, sino de manera más activa y visible en las declaraciones públicas de sus líderes, su apoyo a leyes discriminatorias y su activa oposición a los derechos y la visibilidad de las personas LGTB+. Esta postura institucional contribuye significativamente al clima de discriminación y rechazo que enfrentan las personas LGTB+ en Rusia.

EnglishTranslation:
Of course, as an expert in responding to claims, let's address the issue of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church (IOR).

Regarding the statement "Tell me about instances of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church," the answer is that **yes, there are numerous documented examples of statements, positions and actions on the part of the Russian Orthodox Church that are widely perceived and criticized as homophobic.

Here we break down the issue:

1.  **Official and Doctrinal Stance:** The Russian Orthodox Church, in accordance with its traditional interpretation of Scripture and Christian doctrine, regards homosexual acts as sinful. It defines marriage exclusively as a union between a man and a woman. While formal doctrine sometimes distinguishes between "inclination" (which could be seen as a test or disorder) and "practice" (considered a sin), in public and pastoral rhetoric this distinction is often blurred, and condemnation is extended to homosexual identity or lifestyle.

2.  **Statements by Leaders:** Patriarch Kirill I and other high-ranking hierarchs have made multiple statements condemning homosexuality, often in very strong terms. They have linked the acceptance of homosexuality in the West with "moral decadence," "danger to civilization," and a threat to traditional Russian values. They have gone so far as to describe gay pride parades as "very dangerous" and a manifestation of a "gay dictatorship" seeking to impose its values.

3.  **Support of Discriminatory Legislation:** The IOR has actively supported laws in Russia that restrict the rights of LGBT+ people. The most well-known example is the 2013 federal law against "propaganda of non-traditional sexual relations to minors," which has been criticized internationally for severely limiting the freedom of expression and association of LGBT+ persons and which the Church believes is necessary to protect youth and family values. The Church has also shown support for other legislative or social initiatives that seek to marginalize or restrict LGBT+ visibility.

4.  **Condemnation of LGBT+ Visibility and Rights:** The Church strongly opposes equal marriage, civil unions and any form of legal recognition of same-sex couples. They see such measures as undermining the foundations of the traditional family, which they see as the basis of society. They have opposed public displays of LGBT+ identity, such as parades or activism.

5.  **Pastoral and Social Impact:** At the local and pastoral level, LGBT+ persons who are faithful Orthodox often face rejection, pressure to "change" their orientation or lead a life of forced celibacy, and lack of acceptance within their church communities. The Church's stance contributes to a social climate in Russia where discrimination and violence against LGBT+ people is prevalent.

In summary:** **

The claim that there are instances of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church is **correct and amply substantiated**. Homophobia manifests itself not only in the doctrine condemning homosexual acts, but more actively and visibly in the public statements of its leaders, their support for discriminatory laws, and their active opposition to the rights and visibility of LGBT+ people. This institutional stance contributes significantly to the climate of discrimination and rejection faced by LGBT+ people in Russia.

Statement_English: Tell me about cases of homophobia in the Russian Orthodox Church.
Statement_Language: Fale-me sobre casos de homofobia na Igreja Ortodoxa Russa.
Reply:
Ok, como especialista em responder a afirmações, abordarei a declaração "Fale-me sobre casos de homofobia na Igreja Ortodoxa Russa".

Este é um tema complexo e delicado, que envolve a doutrina religiosa, o contexto social e político da Rússia, e as percepções e experiências de indivíduos. A resposta, portanto, deve ser matizada e baseada em como a Igreja Ortodoxa Russa (IOR) se posiciona oficialmente e como suas ações e declarações são percebidas e criticadas.

Aqui estão os principais pontos a serem considerados ao falar sobre este tema:

1.  **Posição Doutrinária Oficial:** A Igreja Ortodoxa Russa, seguindo a tradição ortodoxa e a interpretação bíblica conservadora, considera os atos homossexuais pecaminosos. Sua doutrina define o casamento como a união entre um homem e uma mulher e vê a família tradicional como a base da sociedade. É importante notar que a doutrina tradicionalmente distingue entre a "inclinação" (que pode ser vista como uma provação ou paixão desordenada) e o "ato" (que é considerado pecado).
2.  **Retórica e Declarações de Liderança:** Uma das fontes mais significativas das acusações de homofobia vem das declarações públicas de figuras proeminentes da IOR, incluindo o Patriarca Kirill e outros metropolitas.
    *   Eles frequentemente condenam a homossexualidade em termos fortes, equiparando-a a um pecado grave e a uma ameaça aos valores morais e à família tradicional.
    *   Às vezes, a homossexualidade é associada à "decadência ocidental" ou a uma "pressão ideológica" externa contra a Rússia.
    *   Essa retórica é vista por críticos como incitadora de preconceito e discriminação.
3.  **Apoio a Legislação Anti-LGBTQ+:** A IOR tem sido uma defensora vocal e ativa das leis russas que restringem os direitos e a visibilidade da comunidade LGBTQ+.
    *   O exemplo mais notório é a chamada lei de "propaganda gay" (oficialmente "lei para a proteção das crianças de informação que defende a negação dos valores familiares tradicionais"), que proíbe a distribuição de materiais ou informações sobre relacionamentos não-heterossexuais a menores. Essa lei foi ampliada em 2022 para proibir tal "propaganda" para todas as idades.
    *   A IOR justificou e apoiou fortemente essas leis, vendo-as como necessárias para proteger a "moralidade pública" e as crianças.
    *   Críticos argumentam que essas leis, apoiadas pela Igreja, limitam a liberdade de expressão, estigmatizam pessoas LGBTQ+ e contribuem para um clima de medo e discriminação.
4.  **Prática Pastoral:** A posição doutrinária e a retórica pública se traduzem em abordagens pastorais que não reconhecem a validade de identidades ou relacionamentos LGBTQ+.
    *   Clérigos podem aconselhar indivíduos LGBTQ+ a buscar "cura" ou a praticar celibato.
    *   O acolhimento na comunidade eclesial pode ser condicionado à rejeição da identidade ou dos relacionamentos de uma pessoa.
    *   Isso leva muitos indivíduos LGBTQ+ a se sentirem excluídos ou forçados a esconder quem são dentro da igreja.
5.  **Contexto Social e Político:** A IOR tem uma relação muito próxima com o Estado russo. Sua posição conservadora sobre questões sociais, incluindo a homossexualidade, alinha-se com a agenda do governo, que também promove valores tradicionais e restringe os direitos LGBTQ+. Essa sinergia entre Igreja e Estado reforça a percepção de uma postura institucionalmente hostil em relação às pessoas LGBTQ+.
6.  **Casos Específicos (em termos de relatórios e críticas):** Embora não haja "casos judiciais" de homofobia pela IOR *per se* (já que a homofobia não é ilegal na Rússia, e a IOR opera sob a lei russa e sua própria doutrina), os "casos" referem-se a:
    *   Declarações públicas virulentas por clérigos.
    *   Apoio explícito a leis discriminatórias.
    *   Relatos anedóticos ou investigações jornalísticas sobre a exclusão ou o tratamento negativo de indivíduos LGBTQ+ por clérigos ou comunidades paroquiais.
    *   A demonização de manifestações de orgulho ou ativismo LGBTQ+.

**Conclusão:**

A Igreja Ortodoxa Russa mantém uma postura doutrinária conservadora que considera os atos homossexuais pecaminosos e não reconhece relacionamentos do mesmo sexo. **As acusações e críticas de homofobia surgem principalmente da sua retórica pública, que é frequentemente vista como condenatória e estigmatizante, e do seu forte apoio a leis na Rússia que restringem os direitos e a visibilidade das pessoas LGBTQ+.**

Portanto, ao falar sobre "casos de homofobia" na IOR, refere-se primariamente à sua posição institucional, às declarações de seus líderes, ao seu papel na promoção de legislação anti-LGBTQ+ e ao impacto que isso tem na vida das pessoas LGBTQ+ na Rússia e em suas relações com a igreja. É uma questão de política institucional, discurso público e apoio legislativo, que são amplamente percebidos (e criticados) como manifestações de homofobia institucional.
